snippet: Republicans hoping to halt Donald J. Trump’s march to the nomination emerged from the weekend newly emboldened by his uneven electoral performance and by some signs that he may be peaking with voters.
abstract: Republicans wanting to halt surge of Donald J Trump to party's presidential nomination are seeing early indications he is peaking with voters; outside groups are spending more than $10 million in new anti-Trump ads in Florida and additional millions in Illinois, portraying him as liberal huckster.

byline.original: By MATT FLEGENHEIMER and MAGGIE HABERMAN
byline.contributor: Jonathan Martin, Jeremy W. Peters and Thomas Kaplan contributed reporting.

lead_paragraph: Republicans hoping to halt Donald J. Trump’s march to the nomination emerged from the weekend newly emboldened by his uneven electoral performance and by some signs that he may be peaking with voters.

headline.main: Money Pours In as Move to Stop Donald Trump Expands
headline.print_headline: Money Pours In as Move to Stop Trump Sharpens
